title: Swedbank Ousts Executives in Estonian Unit Amid Internal Probe
text:
Swedbank said it replaced three executives in its Estonian division amid an ongoing internal investigation.

Swedbank AB said it removed three executives and appointed permanent leaders in its troubled Estonian division as part of its probe into allegations of weak anti-money-laundering compliance.

The bank said Monday that it terminated Robert Kitt and Vaiko Tammeväli, the division’s former chief executive and chief financial officers, respectively, who were suspended from their roles in June. It also ousted Kaie Metsla, head of the bank’s private customer division.

The moves were a result of shortcomings that Swedbank identified as part of its ongoing probe into allegations that dirty money, much of it from Russia, flowed through its Estonian division, the bank said.

Newsletter Sign-up “Removing three appreciated leaders from their positions is a tough decision to make,” Björn Elfstrand, council chair of Swedbank Estonia, said in a statement. “However, it is a consequence of the bank’s ongoing internal investigation.” Swedbank said no criminal activities have been identified as part of the probe. The bank declined to comment Tuesday beyond its previous statement. Swedbank named Olavi Lepp as permanent CEO of the Estonian division. Mr. Lepp has served as acting CEO since June and, before that, was chief risk officer. Anna Kõuts, acting CFO of the Estonian unit and previous head of treasury, was named permanent CFO. Additionally, Tarmo Ulla will succeed Ms. Metsla as head of private banking. Ms. Ulla was head of lending support for Swedbank in the Baltics, according to a LinkedIn profile in her name. Swedbank for months has been working to move past a scandal ignited by a February report by Swedish TV network SVT that 50 suspicious customers moved at least $4 billion through the bank between 2007 and 2015. European and U.S. authorities have opened investigations into the bank’s management of money-laundering risks. Swedbank, meanwhile, has reshuffled its executive ranks and hired law firm Clifford Chance to conduct an investigation into shortcomings in the bank’s anti-money-laundering controls.
